function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"X grain-fed sheep, fat-tailed","confidence":"medium","notes":"Pattern matches examples like \"NUMB udu niga\" = \"NUMB sheep, barley-fed\" and \"NUMB gukkal niga\" = \"NUMB fat-tailed ewe, barley-fed\". \"i\" likely = \"fat-tailed\" (common descriptor for sheep); \"ukim\" = \"grain-fed\" (variant of \"niga\"). \"X\" as placeholder numeral/name."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"under seal of Ur-nigar","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches Example 104: \"kicib urnigar\" → \"under seal of Ur-nigar\". Common Ur III administrative phrase indicating a sealed document or transaction authenticated by the named individual, Ur-nigar."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Gilgameš","confidence":"high","notes":"Proper name of the legendary king of Uruk, hero of the Epic of Gilgameš, often appearing in Sumerian royal and literary contexts."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"field of Ur-gigir, the household administrator","confidence":"high","notes":"GAN = field; urgigir = personal name Ur-gigir; cabra = household administrator/steward (šà-tam). Matches Ur III administrative style for field attributions to officials (cf. examples 133, 186, 247, 264, 908, 981, 996)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"from Akika","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches numerous examples like \"ki amarcubata\" = \"from Amar-šuba\", \"ki naramilita\" = \"from Naram-ilī\", \"ki urnungal dumu erindata\" = \"from Ur-Ningal son of Erinda\". \"Akika\" is a personal name, likely the source or origin in an administrative context."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Ur-Baba","confidence":"high","notes":"Proper name of a person, commonly appearing in Ur III administrative texts as e.g. a plowman or official (cf. examples 620, 678, 984)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"superintendent","confidence":"high","notes":"nubanda(gu): chief livestock administrator or superintendent, common title in Ur III administrative texts (cf. examples 137, 879: \"nubanda\", \"Kuda nubanda\")."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB male laborers , NUMB shekels , NUMB barley","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matching administrative ration texts: guruc = male laborers; gin = shekels (likely silver); ceta = barley. NUMB as placeholders for numerals. Cf. examples like NUMB sila kac NUMB sila ninda (rations in sila3), NUMB gin i NUMB gin naga (shekels of commodities), and labor contexts like NUMB guruc u NUMB (male laborer days)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"a field of it","confidence":"high","notes":"surface area: NUMB sar NUMB shekels ; cf. example 527 \"acabi : a field of it\" and example 342 \"saharbi NUMB saram : its soil : NUMB sar\""}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Lu-Enki","confidence":"high","notes":"Personal name, following the pattern of Sumerian anthroponyms like Lu-Inanna (Example 992), Lu-Ningirsu (Example 271), etc., where \"lu\" means \"man/person\" and \"Enki\" is the god name."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB tugur","confidence":"medium","notes":"Likely \"NUMB tugur\" refers to a quantity (NUMB) of a type of garment or textile known as \"tugur\" from Ur III administrative contexts, possibly a specific linen or woolen cloth; cf. similar textile allocations like \"NUMB gada gal saga\" (Example 865) or \"tug ninkicara\" (Example 281). Exact rendering of \"tugur\" uncertain without full context."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Lugal-musu-da","confidence":"high","notes":"Personal name, likely \"Lugal-mūsuda\" or \"Lugal-musuda\", following the pattern of names like Lugal-ezem, Lugal-ḫegal, etc., in Ur III administrative texts (cf. examples 146, 319, 355, etc.)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB še-zibītum","confidence":"medium","notes":"Likely \"NUMB (shekels of) še-zibītum\", where še-zibītum is a type of grain or barley variety (possibly \"zibītum barley\" or a specific cultivar/quality); common in Ur III economic texts for measured quantities of cereals. Pattern matches examples like \"NUMB cebi NUMB sila gur\" (its barley: NUMB sila3) or \"NUMB gin suhe\" (NUMB shekels of suhe)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB field surface , Ur-gigir","confidence":"high","notes":"Follows standard Ur III field accounting format: NUMB (iku/bur3) GAN (field surface/area); ug (foreman/overseer): Ur-gigir. Cf. examples like NUMB GAN gecura (396), NUMB GAN absinbi (197)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"month : “ Amar-aša ” ,","confidence":"high","notes":"Standard Ur III month name referring to a festival or event involving Amar-aša (likely a deity or place name); matches pattern of examples like \"iti ceila\" = month “ Barley carried ”."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"sheep of Munagigi","confidence":"high","notes":"Following patterns like \"ludaba\" = \"daba men\", \"luzabala unu\" = \"Lu-Zabala, the cowherd\", \"silasig engar\" = \"Silasig, the plowman\". \"udu\" = sheep; \"munagigi\" is a personal name (variant of Munagi or similar, common in Ur III texts)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"the person who the temple of Ninsun","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches example 574: \"lu e ninunuka\" = \"the person who the temple of Ninunu\". \"Ninsun\" is the goddess Nin-sun, replacing \"ninunuka\". Refers to someone associated with or entering the temple of Ninsun."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"grand total : NUMB","confidence":"high","notes":"guniginba is a common Ur III term for \"altogether\" or \"grand total\" in administrative summaries, often followed by a numeral (NUMB)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"foreman : Idab","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches pattern in examples like \"ugula namhani\" = \"foreman : Namḫani\" (Ex. 41), \"ugula lukala\" = \"foreman : Lukalla\" (Ex. 70)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"ki urnigarta","confidence":"high","notes":"Standard Ur III administrative phrase meaning \"from Ur-nigar\" or \"from the account of Ur-nigar\", matching pattern in examples like ki lugula (from Lugula), ki amarcubata (from Amar-šuba), etc. Ur-nigar is a common personal name in these contexts."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"of …","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches pattern from Example 100: \"X\" → \"of …-al\" and Example 369: \"X\" → \"of …\", as well as numerous similar lacuna or undetermined elements in administrative and lexical contexts from Ur III texts where a single undetermined sign (X) indicates a damaged or unreadable name, title, or element, typically rendered as \"of …\"."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB field area : Ure-maḫ , son of Ur-Šila-luh","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches administrative land records (e.g., Ex. 985: NUMB GAN NUMB dam akala; Ex. 411: NUMB GAN NUMB). Ure-maḫ is a personal name (cf. Ur-e-maḫe in Ex. 339, 804); Ur-šila-luh is a personal name (ursilaluh = Ur-Šila-luh, compound name with šila 'hair' + luh 'wash')."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB sila3 NUMB shekels of flour","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches administrative ration lists (e.g., Example 62: NUMB sila kac...; Example 159: NUMB sila NUMB gin i...; Example 347: NUMB ninda NUMB gin i...). 'NUMB sila' = volume measure (sila3); 'NUMB gin' = weight measure (shekels); 'celu' = flour (common in Ur III economic texts)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB shekels oil , NUMB shekels potash ,","confidence":"high","notes":"Direct match to examples 575 and 884; standard Ur III ration terminology for oil (i) and alkali-plant/potash (naga) measured in shekels (gin)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"total : NUMB sila3 barley , emmer","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matching examples: \"cunigin NUMB sila ce gur\" → \"total : NUMB , NUMB sila3 barley\"; \"cebi NUMB sila gur\" → \"its barley : NUMB sila3\". \"ziz\" is emmer wheat (zíz), a common grain alongside \"ce\" (barley). Ur III administrative total for measured grain quantities."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"from Ur-suda","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches pattern of Ur III administrative texts where \"ki PNta\" indicates \"from [personal name]\". Cf. examples 26: ki amarcubata \"from Amar-šuba\"; 39: ki abasagata \"from Abbasaga\"; 118: ki urhalmucata \"from Ur-Ḫalmuša\". \"Ur-suda\" is a common Sumerian personal name (Ur-suda)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB field surface , porter foreman :","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matching: \"NUMB GAN\" = field surface/area (e.g., Ex. 302, 411, 956); \"ug luga\" = foreman porter (cf. \"ugIL\" = porters, Ex. 681, 774; \"ugula\" = foreman, widespread; Ur III administrative context for labor/field records)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"year : “ The high-priestess of Inanna by means of extispicy was chosen ; ”","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches Example 68 and Example 515 exactly. Standard Ur III year formula for the selection of a high priestess (en) via divination (mace ipa = 'by goat/extispicy')."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB field Ur-nigar","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches examples such as \"NUMB GAN gecura ara NUMB GANta\" (field measurements), \"aca urninti\" (field Ur-Ninti), \"aca ninura\" (field of Nin-ura). \"Ur-nigar\" is a common personal name (cf. examples 104, 832). \"GAN\" denotes field surface or plot in Ur III administrative contexts."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"from Nabasa","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches pattern \"ki [person]\" = \"from [person]\" (cf. Ex. 612: ki nabasata = from Nabasa). \"Apa\" likely a variant or scribal form of \"ki\" (from), with \"nabasata\" as a personal name in genitive."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"mua bedam","confidence":"medium","notes":"Uncertain; possibly \"reed boat has split\" or similar, based on \"ihac\" = \"has split open\" (ex. 386) and boat contexts. \"Mua\" may refer to a type of boat (cf. \"ma\" in boating terms like ex. 8, 540). Alternatively, \"year of the split\" if \"mu-a\". Matches administrative phrasing for damaged goods or events."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"head of the courtyard, daba men","confidence":"high","notes":"sag = head; kisala = courtyard (common in temple/administrative contexts); daba = conveyance/sale (per ex.1), often with personnel like \"daba men\". Fits Ur III administrative style for personnel or property designation."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"harrowed NUMB (times)","confidence":"high","notes":"Common in agricultural contexts (cf. Examples 23, 835: ara NUMB GANta = harrowed once / NUMB times)"}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB long ninda NUMB wide cubits NUMB high cubits","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches administrative descriptions of dimensions, akin to Ex. 698 (NUMB ninda du NUMB kuc gid = \"NUMB running ninda NUMB cubits the length\"). Here, ninda gid (\"long ninda\"), kuc dagal (\"wide cubit\"), kuc sukud (\"high cubit\"). Typical for measuring objects like beds, tables, or storage vessels in Ur III texts."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"and sealed documents of the conveyance","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches example 76 \"kicib daba\" = \"sealed documents of conveyance\"; prefixed \"u\" = \"and\" as in numerous examples (e.g., 107, 166, 377). Common in Ur III administrative texts for \"and under seal of the tablet(s) of transfer.\""}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB old garments , overseer","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matching example 309 \"tug nindanirgal\" = \"textile (for) Ninda-nirgal\"; \"tug\" = garment/textile; \"cagadu\" likely \"sa-gadu\" or overseer/supervisor (common title, cf. administrative roles); \"sumun\" = old/ancient. Thus, NUMB old overseer-garments."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB suckling male lamb","confidence":"high","notes":"gaUD@g transliterates a young lamb still nursing (ga 'milk'; UD@g 'young/offspring'). Matches pattern in Ex. 258: NUMB kir ga = NUMB suckling female lamb; Ex. 750: NUMB mac ga = NUMB suckling male kid. Common in Ur III livestock/administrative texts for age/condition of ovicaprids."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB female gazelle calves","confidence":"high","notes":"Follows pattern of animal designations in administrative texts (e.g., \"NUMB amar macda\" = NUMB calf-gazelles in example 112). \"Amar\" = calf; \"macda\" = gazelle; \"munus\" = female."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB sila3 , NUMB shekels suckling lambs","confidence":"high","notes":"Follows common Ur III patterns for animal rations or offerings: NUMB sila3 (volume measure, likely barley/flour), NUMB shekels (weight, possibly silver or associated), gaUD@g (likely ga-ùĝ for \"suckling lamb\" or kid, cf. examples 257, 750, 874, 878 for suckling lambs/kids); gur as total measure or container."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"via Kaš","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches examples like \"giri nannamaba\" = \"Via : Nanna-maba\", \"giri urtirac\" = \"via Ur-Tiraš\", \"giri bazi\" = \"via Bazi\". \"Giri kas\" indicates agency or mediation \"via/by Kaš\" (proper name, likely a person)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"of …","confidence":"medium","notes":"Matches patterns in examples such as Example 100 (\"of …-al\"), Example 369 (\"of …\"), Example 407 (\"( for ) …\"), Example 748 (\"from …\"), where \"X\" indicates a damaged or unreadable name or term, commonly translated as \"of …\" or similar fragmentary phrase in administrative or dedicatory contexts."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"its clarified butter : NUMB sila NUMB shekels","confidence":"high","notes":"Follows Ur III administrative patterns for quantified commodities (cf. Ex. 328: NUMB sila inun NUMB sila gar; \"inun\" = clarified butter/ghee; \"bi\" = possessive/reflexive suffix; units structured as volume then weight, typical for dairy products)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"mouth of the canal","confidence":"high","notes":"Common Sumerian administrative term for the mouth or inlet of a canal (buraĝ), often in field or irrigation contexts (cf. examples like ka ida puzurmamace)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Lu-Namanka","confidence":"high","notes":"Personal name, following the pattern of Sumerian anthroponyms like Lu-Nanna, Lu-Baba, etc., where \"lu-\" is a common element in names meaning \"man/person of,\" and \"Namanka\" is the theophoric or descriptive element."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"year : “ Amar-Suen , the king , Urbilum destroyed . ”","confidence":"high","notes":"Standard Ur III year formula. Matches Example 599 and 715 exactly. \"mu\" = year; \"amarsuen lugale\" = Amar-Suen, the king; \"urbilum muhul\" = Urbilum destroyed."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"with oil, cheese, fish and vegetables punted","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches pattern from example 540: \"apisalta nibruce ma i ga ku nisi gida u ma gura\" translated as \"from Apisal to Nippur barge with oil, cheese, fish and vegetables punted and barge returned.\" \"im dua gida\" is a partial phrase referring to punting a barge loaded with clarified butter/oil (i), cheese (ga), fish (ku), and vegetables (nisi gida)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Tir-ula accepted","confidence":"high","notes":"tir likely a personal name (Tir-), ula a name or term (cf. similar names like Ur-ula), idab \"accepted; received\" (common in administrative contexts, matching patterns like \"endingirmu idab\", \"intaea idab\", \"ursusu idab\")."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"and his father … , Mini-ilī","confidence":"medium","notes":"Pattern matches examples like \"dumu X\" (son of …), \"ludaba\" (daba men), personal names with IL (divine element common in Sumerian/Akkadian names, e.g., Naram-ilī). \"u ane\" likely \"and his father\"; X is placeholder; \"miniIL\" interpreted as personal name Mini-ilī (cf. Ex. 4, 10, 26, etc.)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"son of Na-silim","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches pattern in Example 18 (silasig engar: Silasig, the plowman) and Example 339 (dumu uremahe: son of Ur-Emaḫe), where \"dumu PN\" translates as \"son of [personal name]\". \"Nasilim\" is a known personal name (cf. Example 170, 357)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"total : NUMB male laborers , rations","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matching examples like \"cunigin NUMB guruc u NUMB\" = \"NUMB male laborer days\" and \"cunigin NUMB geme u NUMB\" = \"total : NUMB , NUMB female laborer days\". \"Nudab\" refers to rations or allocations in Ur III administrative contexts."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB male laborer workdays","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches pattern from Example 285: \"NUMB guruc u NUMB\" = \"NUMB male laborer days\". Common Ur III labor accounting terminology where \"guruc\" (or \"gurusz\") denotes male laborers and \"u\" workdays."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB shekels (of) tablet(s)","confidence":"high","notes":"DUBla is a compound form referring to \"tablets\" (plural of DUB 'tablet'), commonly used in Ur III administrative contexts for documents or clay tablets. \"NUMB gin\" indicates a quantity in shekels, likely of silver or another material associated with sealed tablets or their value. Cf. similar economic notations in examples like NUMB gin suhe or NUMB gin i."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"bizu","confidence":"medium","notes":"Uncertain term; possibly a personal name (e.g., Bi-zu), place name, or abbreviation in administrative context. Not directly matching examples; may refer to \"reed mat\" or similar in Ur III texts, but literal rendering preserves form."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Nurma , bansi-weaver","confidence":"high","notes":"Follows common Ur III naming pattern (proper name + occupation/profession), as seen in examples like \"luzu sipa\" (Lu-Utu, the shepherd), \"luzabala unu\" (Lu-Zabala, the cowherd), and \"silasig engar\" (Silasig, the plowman). \"Bansi\" refers to a type of linen or linen garment, with \"bansi\" as the weaver or specialist thereof."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB sheep , barley-fed , NUMB top grade","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches examples like \"NUMB udu niga NUMB us\" (e.g., Ex. 592: NUMB sheep, barley-fed, of ordNUMB grade) and \"NUMB gu niga sagu\" (Ex. 730: NUMB oxen, barley-fed, top grade). \"niga\" = barley-fed; \"us gula\" = top/first grade (cf. \"sagu\" = top grade)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB shekels of clarified butter","confidence":"high","notes":"Follows standard Ur III administrative terminology for quantified clarified butter (inun), measured in shekels (gin); cf. similar patterns like \"NUMB sila inun\" (Example 328) and \"NUMB gin i\" (oil in shekels)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB hachur cergu","confidence":"medium","notes":"Uncertain term; \"hachur\" may refer to a type of garment or linen (cf. hagur), \"cergu\" possibly \"sergu\" or yoke-related (cergu), perhaps \"NUMB linen yoke(s)\" or \"NUMB hachur field oxen\"; context suggests administrative allocation, possibly clothing or equipment."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB Carazida","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern-matched to personal or place names like \"kardaka\" → \"of Karda\" or \"Simanum\" → \"Simānum\"; \"carazida\" is a proper name (likely Kara-zida or similar), with NUMB indicating a quantity or allocation associated with it, common in Ur III administrative contexts for allotments or personnel."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"and Mactaba","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches examples like \"ludaba\" = \"daba men\", \"lusaizu\" = \"of Lu-sa-izu\", \"lubaba\" = \"Lu-Baba\". \"u\" = \"and\"; \"mactaba\" = personal name (cf. Maštab, common in Ur III onomasticon)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"sipa kalamace","confidence":"high","notes":"Direct match to Example 110: 'sipa kalamace' translates to 'as the shepherd of his country'. Common Ur III royal epithet referring to the king as shepherd of the land/realm."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB by Atanah","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches examples like \"NUMB abumdingir\" = \"NUMB by Abum-ilum\" (Ex. 4) and \"NUMB X\" = \"NUMB by …-num\" (Ex. 12). \"Atanah\" is a personal name in genitive/dative case, indicating agency or origin (\"by/from [person]\")."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"siskur-offering of milk, ox-fat","confidence":"high","notes":"siskur = offering/ritual presentation (common in Ur III religious/administrative contexts); ga = milk; guce (or gu še) = ox-fat or suet, typical in sacrificial lists alongside animals/fluids."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"and NUMB barley threshed, and boat loaded","confidence":"high","notes":"Follows Ur III administrative patterns: \"ce gec ea\" = threshed barley (cf. Ex. 211); \"ma siga\" = boat loaded (cf. Ex. 812). \"u NUMB\" = and NUMB (workdays or quantity)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"field of I-lugal-ka","confidence":"high","notes":"Follows standard Ur III administrative pattern for field designations (e.g., \"aca X\" = \"field X\"), with \"i lugalka\" as a proper name or field label, similar to examples like \"aca ninudu\" (field “Nin-nudu”), \"aca ducara\" (field of Du-Šara), and \"aca carahuma\" (Šaraḫuma)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Ur-Dublamaḫ","confidence":"high","notes":"Personal name, likely \"Ur-Dub-lamaḫ\" (Ur, servant of the great Lamaḫ temple or similar compound); common Ur III naming pattern (proper name of a person, often an official or laborer)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Geme-nunga-lake","confidence":"high","notes":"Proper name of a female person (Geme-Nunga-lake), following the pattern of Sumerian personal names like \"Geme-[deity]-[epithet]\" seen in examples such as \"geme ucbaram\" (female weaver personnel) or \"Geme-ekare\". \"Gemenunga\" is a known name element; \"lake\" likely a locative or epithet."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Šalia","confidence":"high","notes":"Personal name, likely a proper noun referring to an individual (common in Ur III administrative texts as a recipient, worker, or owner). The comma represents the š sign in cuneiform transliteration."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"the deficit : NUMB mana NUMB shekels NUMB grains of silver","confidence":"high","notes":"Direct match to Example 711: \"laia NUMB mana NUMB gin NUMB ce kubabbar\" translated as \"Deficit : NUMB mana , NUMB shekels , NUMB grains of silver\". \"Laia\" indicates deficit or shortfall in administrative accounts; \"kubabbar\" is silver; units are minas (mana), shekels (gin), and grains (ce). Ur III economic terminology."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"of …","confidence":"medium","notes":"Matches pattern from Example 100: \"X\" → \"of …-al\" and Example 369: \"X\" → \"of …\", typical for damaged or unidentified personal/deity name in administrative context."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"year : “ Enmahgalana , priestess of Nanna , was installed ; ”","confidence":"high","notes":"Standard Ur III year formula (cf. examples 85, 194, 266, 493, 666, 973). \"enmahgalana\" = Enmaḫ-gal-ana (personal name), \"nanna\" = Nanna (moon god), \"bahun\" = was installed/hired (as priestess)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB long garments","confidence":"high","notes":"Follows pattern of textile descriptions like \"NUMB gada gal saga\" (Example 865: NUMB linens, good quality). \"gada\" = linen/flax garment; \"gadul\" = long/large variant."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB (gur) emmer, under seal of Lu-utu, foreman of the mill","confidence":"high","notes":"Follows Ur III administrative patterns: NUMB ziz = quantity of emmer wheat (ziz commonly denotes emmer); gur = standard measure; kicib = \"under seal of\"; lutu = personal name Lu-utu (cf. ex. 78); ugula kikken = \"foreman of the mill\" (kikken = millhouse, common in grain processing texts)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"ki cunamugita","confidence":"high","notes":"Standard Ur III administrative phrase indicating source or origin \"from the account of Cunamu(g)\" or \"from Šu-namu(g)'s (account)\". Matches pattern of examples like \"ki abasagata\" = \"from Abbasaga\", \"ki naramilita\" = \"from Naram-ilī\". \"Cunamug\" likely personal name (var. Šu-namug), common in Girsu texts for an official or estate holder."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"month “Sowing”","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches Example 321: Sumerian: iti cunumunta → English: from month “Sowing”. Here, without directional particle, standard month name translation from Ur III administrative texts."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB (mana wool for) Ma-sab, NUMB","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches wool allocations like \"NUMB ninama\" = \"NUMB (mana wool for) Nin-ama\"; \"masab\" interpreted as personal name Ma-sab, common in Ur III administrative texts for allotments."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"and the head plowman of the E-Ninhursag","confidence":"high","notes":"Sumerian \"u\" = \"and\"; \"sag\" = \"head/chief\"; \"apin\" = \"plowman\"; \"e\" = \"house/temple\"; \"ninhursag\" = \"Ninhursag\" (goddess, often associated with temples named E-Ninhursag). Matches administrative patterns for personnel titles in Ur III texts (cf. examples like \"sipa unu\", \"ugula engar\")."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"of …","confidence":"medium","notes":"Matches pattern from Example 100: \"X\" → \"of …-al\" and Example 369: \"X\" → \"of …\", typical for damaged or unreadable names in Sumerian administrative texts."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"account of Kalla","confidence":"high","notes":"Follows pattern of \"nigkak [PN]\" (e.g., Ex. 834: nigkak abamu = account of Abbamu). \"Kala\" is a personal name, as in Ex. 695: kala = (from) Kalla; Ex. 790: kala engar = Kalla, the plowman."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB lambs , NUMB shekels each","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matching examples like \"NUMB sila NUMB ginta\" (844: NUMB rams , NUMB shekels each) and \"NUMB sila NUMB gin\" (922: NUMB lamb , NUMB shekels). \"gu balabi\" interpreted as \"lambs\" (gu = lambs/male kids; bala = exchange or distributive plural marker), with NUMB specifying quantity and NUMB gin the per-unit silver price, common in Ur III economic texts for priced livestock."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Akala, leatherworker","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matching examples like \"lutu sipa\" = Lu-Utu, the shepherd; \"urcarake inla\" = Ur-Šara weighed; \"silasig engar\" = Silasig, the plowman. \"Akala\" is a personal name; \"acgab\" (ačgab) is a profession meaning leatherworker or leather preparer, common in Ur III administrative texts for workers handling leather goods."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"enancekiag","confidence":"high","notes":"Standard Sumerian epithet: en-ana-ke4-ĝu10, \"my beloved lord\" or \"his beloved master/lord\". Common in royal inscriptions and dedicatory texts, often referring to a deity or king as the speaker's cherished ruler. Matches patterns in examples like \"lugal ca kuge padanir\" (Example 54)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB royal gur of fine flour","confidence":"high","notes":"Follows standard Ur III administrative terminology: NUMB = numeral placeholder; zi sig = fine flour; gur = capacity measure (approx. 300 liters); lugal = royal (standard measure, typically larger than common measures). Cf. examples like \"NUMB ce gur lugal\" (20,220), \"NUMB sila zi sig gur\" (338), \"NUMB zi sig\" (539)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB (gur) , Dug-…","confidence":"medium","notes":"Pattern matching examples like \"NUMB gur urani\" → \"NUMB , Urrani ;\" and \"NUMB kicib lugaldam\" → \"NUMB ( gur ) Lugal-dam ,\" where NUMB likely represents a quantity (e.g., gur of grain), followed by a personal name beginning with \"dug\" (common in Sumerian names like Dug-X). The X X indicate damaged or partial name elements."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB (mana wool for) Kikken, the leatherworker","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches wool allocations like \"NUMB gemedardu\" = \"NUMB (mana wool for) Geme-dardu\". \"Kikken\" is a personal name; \"carazam(e)\" is a profession/title meaning leatherworker or leather preparer, common in Ur III administrative texts for specialists handling hides/leather."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"of Lu-sa-izu","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches Example 371: \"lusaizu\" → \"of Lu-sa-izu\". Common personal name format in Ur III administrative texts, indicating possession or origin (\"ki\" implied or contextual)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"under seal of Ur-Šulpa'e","confidence":"high","notes":"Common Ur III administrative phrase \"kicib PN\" translates to \"under seal of [personal name]\". Matches pattern in examples like 104 (kicib urnigar: under seal of Ur-nigar), 399 (kicib adaga: sealed tablet of Adaga), and numerous others. Ur-Šulpa'e (urculpae) is a frequent proper name in these contexts, often a merchant (cf. example 359)."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"under seal of Uludi","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matching examples 13 (kicib cuea sukkalmah: under seal of Šu-Ea , chief minister), 104 (kicib urnigar: under seal of Ur-nigar), 137 (kicib kuda nubanda: under seal of Kuda , the superintendent), etc. \"kicib\" consistently translates as \"under seal of\" or \"sealed documents of\" followed by a personal name; \"uludi\" is a personal name analogous to Ur-nigar, Lu-Baba, etc."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"received from Abbasaga","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches examples like \"cu bati\" = \"received\"; \"ki abasaga\" = \"from Abbasaga\" (ex. 39, 487). \"Cu\" = received; \"abasaga\" = Abbasaga, a personal name."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"month : “ Barley at the quay ; ”","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches Example 356 exactly: \"Sumerian: iti cekaragala English: month : “ Barley at the quay ; ”\". This is a standard month name from the Umma calendar, referring to the month when barley was transported or processed at the quay."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"labor of the hired men, fieldwork","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches pattern from example 212 (\"a lu hunga\" = \"labor of the hired men\") combined with \"acaga\" as \"fieldwork\" (cf. example 856 \"acage kin ak\" = \"fieldwork\"). Typical Ur III labor terminology."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"house fire not","confidence":"medium","notes":"eta = house; izi = fire; la = not/no. Likely \"no house fire\" or \"house without fire,\" possibly referring to a house not burned or a structure lacking fire in an administrative or legal context. Matches patterns of negative phrases in Sumerian texts."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB sila3 of black cumin","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches pattern from Example 32: \"NUMB gamun ge\" → \"… NUMB black cumin\". \"Sila\" is a standard volume measure (sila3); \"gamun\" denotes black cumin (Nigella sativa), common in Ur III administrative texts for spices/seeds."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"bronze pin","confidence":"high","notes":"argibilu (or argi-bilu) refers to a pin or clasp; zabar is bronze, common in Ur III administrative texts for metal objects."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Nisaba","confidence":"high","notes":"Nisaba (or Nidaba): Sumerian goddess of writing, learning, grain, and scribes; often invoked in administrative and scholarly contexts."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"month “ First-fruits , ”","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches Example 830: \"iti nesag\" translated as \"month “ First-fruits , ”\". The suffix \"-ce\" is a common locative or terminative ending in Sumerian administrative texts, often rendered as \"in/at/to\" the month, but in date formulas like the examples, it is typically incorporated into the gloss without explicit preposition for brevity."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"NUMB full-grown billy goats, barley-fed, Nagizu, the messenger to X","confidence":"high","notes":"Follows Ur III patterns: NUMB macgal niga = \"NUMB full-grown billy goats, barley-fed\" (cf. Ex. 6, 397); nagizu = personal name; lu kingia = \"messenger\" (cf. Ex. 307 lu kingia libanugcabac); ca = \"to\" (directional); X = lacuna or unspecified name/place."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Hala received","confidence":"high","notes":"Pattern matches examples like \"cu bati\" = \"received\" (e.g., Ex. 74, 475, 601, 607, 696, 734); personal name \"Hala\" followed by verb phrase, typical in administrative receipts listing recipients of goods/services."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"Tir-inim-e accepted","confidence":"high","notes":"tir-inime is a personal name (variant of Tir-inim-e, common in Ur III administrative texts); idab = \"accepted\" or \"received\" (standard phraseology, cf. examples 191 \"Endingirmu accepted\", 707 \"Ur-susu received\")."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"year : “ Ḫarši , Kimaš were destroyed . ”","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches Example 21 exactly: \"mu harci kimac bahul\" translates to a year formula indicating the destruction of Ḫarši and Kimaš, typical of Ur III royal year names."}

function.name: translate_text
function.arguments: {"translation":"year : “ The house of Šara in Umma was built ; ”","confidence":"high","notes":"Matches example 79 (\"mu e cara badu\" = \"of the year : “ The house of Šara was built ; ”\") with added \"umma\" specifying location in Umma. Common Ur III year formula structure."}
